Description: Scarab carved from stone; underside decorated with an incised motif arranged vertically: to top, winged sun topped by pair of addorsed cobras, and below, winged scarab; in the middle, two t-signs (loaf of bread signs) visible.
Curator's comments: Scarab not yet located, published by Petrie (Petrie 1886, pl. XXXVIII, no. 167). The scarab belongs to Gorton type XII, a type especially well- distributed on Punic sites, but present also in Greece, Cyprus and in Naukratis in Egypt (Gorton 1996, 34-38, type XII). According to the examples discovered in good contexts, this type is attested from around 800 BC till 700 BC (Gorton 1996, 37). It could be one of these early scarabs discovered at Naukratis. On the presence of scarabs predating the occupation of Naukratis: Masson forthcoming. Masson, A. forthcoming, ‘Egyptian Naukratis: the early evidence’, in A. Wodzińska (ed.), Delta and Sinai Current research, Proceedings of the conference in the University of Warsaw, Warsaw, April 25-27 2013. Petrie, W.M.F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVIII, no. 167)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OA.31) (phase 3)
